Inspired by this article, I was introduced to Hugo and GitHub Pages. Iâ€™ve always wanted to build a personal website â€” not just a blog, but one that updates itself regularly with data I collect or subscribe to. This post documents how I combined Cursor, Hugo, GitHub Actions, and GitHub Pages to build an auto-updating personal website.
ğŸ¥… Project Goal Create a clean, Hugo-based personal website and use GitHub Actions as a scheduling engine (like Linux crontab) to regularly run Python scripts for data crawling or dynamic updates. Then, automatically push the new content to GitHub Pages for instant deployment.
ğŸ›  Development Workflow Step 1: Develop with Cursor and Hugo Used Cursor, an AI-enhanced IDE (like VSCode + ChatGPT), for all development. Initialized site using Hugo. Fetched and customized a theme with prompts. Modified layout and content to fit my needs. Tested the site locally. Step 2: Deploy via GitHub Pages Hosted the finished Hugo site using GitHub Pages. ğŸ” Making Static Sites Auto-Update Since Hugo generates static pages, it doesnâ€™t update dynamically. I wanted some sections â€” like data subscriptions, analytics, or newsletters â€” to update regularly.
My Solution: Create a private repo where Python scripts fetch and format dynamic content. Use GitHub Actions with cron syntax to run scripts on a schedule (e.g., daily). Scripts generate updated Markdown or JSON files and push them to the public Hugo repo. GitHub Pages auto-deploys the updated site. ğŸ”— Inspired by this GitHub Actions tutorial:
